texts.shortText: Small and inconspicuous, but quite common. Column smooth with vague longitudinal furrows (marking locations of internal mesenteries); white basally, becoming darker just below the 48 shortish tentacles. Oral disc marked with radiating brown bands and traversed by an orange band running between two longer orange catch tentacles positioned inside the main circle. Outer tentacles each with two brown dots at base, cream basally, outer section crossed by 2–3 brown bands.
Column about 15 mm wide and 20 mm in height.

Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Atlantic coast between about Hondeklip Bay and False Bay.
Primarily reported from intertidal, but records extends down to over 150 m depth. Most commonly found under rock and in sand and gravel in sheltered intertidal sites.
Diet has not been examined but assumed to feed on a variety of smaller invertebrates.
Not specifically known for this species, but most anemones can reproduce both sexually by releasing sperm and eggs into the water, and can also divide by fission.

Colour pattern on disc and habitat fairly distinctive. Often found in the same under boulder-habitat as the similarly small and pale Brooding anemone Helianthella annularis, but that species has only 24 longer tentacles.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 28).

Carlgren, O (1938). South African Actiniaria and Zoantharia. Kungliga Svenska Vetenskapsakademiens Handlingar, 17(3), 1–148.

Laird, MC (2013). Taxonomy, systematics and biodiversity of South African Actiniaria and Corallimorpharia. PhD Thesis, Department of Zoology, University of Cape Town.
